line: Searching the Internet for evidence of time travelers
label: heading

line: Robert J Nemiroff 1, 2 and Teresa Wilson1
label: paragraph

line: Department of Physics, Michigan Technological University, Houghton, MI
label: paragraph

line: Email: nemiroff@mtu.edu
label: paragraph

line: Abstract. Time travel has captured the public imagination for much of the past century,
label: paragraph

line: but little has been done to actually search for time travelers. Here, three implementations
label: paragraph

line: of Internet searches for time travelers are described, all seeking a prescient mention of
label: paragraph

line: information not previously available. The first search covered prescient content placed on
label: paragraph

line: the Internet, highlighted by a comprehensive search for specific terms in tweets on
label: paragraph

line: Twitter. The second search examined prescient inquiries submitted to a search engine,
label: paragraph

line: highlighted by a comprehensive search for specific search terms submitted to a popular
label: paragraph

line: astronomy web site. The third search involved a request for a direct Internet
label: paragraph

line: communication, either by email or tweet, pre-dating to the time of the inquiry. Given
label: paragraph

line: practical verifiability concerns, only time travelers from the future were investigated. No
label: paragraph

line: time travelers were discovered. Although these negative results do not disprove time
label: paragraph

line: travel, given the great reach of
label: paragraph

line: comprehensive to date.
label: paragraph

line: C ontents
label: paragraph

line: 1 . Introduction
label: paragraph

line: 2. Types of Time Travelers
label: heading

line: 3. Searching for Prescient Content on the Internet
label: heading

line: 4. Searching for Prescient Search Queries
label: heading

line: the Internet, this search
label: paragraph

line: 5. Requests for Time Travelers to Issue a Prescient Internet Communication
label: heading

line: 6. Summary and Conclusions
label: heading

line: Acknowledgments
label: heading

line: 1 . Introduction
label: paragraph

line: is perhaps the most
label: paragraph

line: T he origin of the idea of time travel is unknown [1]. Mentions in the distant past include the Indian
label: paragraph

line: Mahabharata [2], which may date as far back as the 9th century BC, the Hebrew Talmud [3], written
label: paragraph

line: about 300 AD, and the Japanese Nihongi [4], which dates back to about 700 AD. A classic contemporary
label: paragraph

line: story of time travel is H. G. Wells' 1895 work "The Time Machine" [5]. All of these, however,
label: paragraph

line: predominantly describe time travel to the future. One of the oldest stories known of time travel to the past
label: paragraph

line: dates only back to 1733 with Samuel Madden's "Memoirs of the Twentieth Century" [6]. Modern fictional
label: paragraph

line: stories involving time travel both to the future and the past are, however, ubiquitous. Two prominent
label: paragraph

line: Author to whom any correspondence should be addressed.
label: paragraph

line: examples include the Doctor Who television series [7] which originated in 1963, and the Back to the
label: paragraph

line: Future film series [8] which began in 1985.
label: paragraph

line: Time travel to the future stands on firm scientific footing. Special Relativity [9] has clear sub-luminal
label: paragraph

line: solutions that correspond with time travel to the future. A famous theoretical example is the twin paradox
label: paragraph

line: [10]. Such future time travel has been experimentally verified, for example, using a pair of clocks one of
label: paragraph

line: which was taken on an airplane. The flying clock recorded a relative time delay of order 10-7 seconds, in
label: paragraph

line: comparison to the more stationary clock [11].
label: paragraph

line: Time travel to the past is controversial, at best, and impossible according to conventional views of the
label: paragraph

line: laws of physics. Formally, Special Relativity allows time travel to the past only for objects moving faster
label: paragraph

line: than the speed of light [12]. In both Special and General Relativity, the possibility that objects could
label: paragraph

line: travel on closed timelike loops would indicate the possibility of time travel to the past. Solutions
label: paragraph

line: involving closed timelike loops have been found in General Relativity with popular cases including
label: paragraph

line: Gödel's universe [13], traveling between black holes and wormholes [14], and circling cosmic strings
label: paragraph

line: [15]. Many physicists consider such solutions unphysical, as articulated, for example, by the Chronology
label: paragraph

line: Protection Conjecture [16].
label: paragraph

line: Although less well known than popular fiction, experiments designed to discover human time travelers
label: paragraph

line: have been conducted. In May of 2005, then graduate student A. Dorai at MIT publicised and held a
label: paragraph

line: convention for time travelers [17]. No one claiming to come from the future showed up [17]. S. Hawking
label: paragraph

line: did a similar experiment in July of 2012, holding a personal party for time travelers, but sending out the
label: paragraph

line: invitations only after the party [18]. No one claiming to be a time traveler showed up [18].
label: paragraph

line: In this work, we report on a series of searches for digital signatures that time travelers potentially left
label: paragraph

line: on the Internet. Specifically, we search for content that should not have been known at the time it was
label: paragraph

line: posted. Such information is here referred to as "prescient". To the best of our knowledge, no similar
label: paragraph

line: search has ever been published previously. Section 2 of this work outlines possible types of time
label: paragraph

line: travelers. Section 3 describes one search for prescient content placed on the Internet, highlighted by a
label: paragraph

line: search of tweets on Twitter. Section 4 describes a search for prescient terms submitted in Internet search
label: paragraph

line: engines, highlighted by a search for two specific terms in the online search engine for the Astronomy
label: paragraph

line: Picture of the Day web site. Section 5 describes an experiment involving the request for a prescient timed
label: paragraph

line: communication to be sent either as a tweet or an email. Section 6 summarizes the results and draws some
label: paragraph

line: conclusions concerning the nature of the results.
label: paragraph

line: 2 . Types of Time Travelers
label: paragraph

line: T ime travelers can be classified as either from the past or from the future. Further subdivisions might
label: paragraph

line: distinguish between time travelers who want to advertise their presence, hide their presence, and those
label: paragraph

line: who are indifferent. We do not consider such distinctions as determinative for search methods employed
label: paragraph

line: here, however, as even time travelers who want to advertise their presence may do so ineffectively, those
label: paragraph

line: who want to hide their presence might make a revealing mistake, and those indifferent might or might not
label: paragraph

line: leave traceable Internet content.
label: paragraph

line: We did not search the Internet for evidence of time travelers from the past. First, we were unable to
label: paragraph

line: conceive of a simple method that would clearly indicate that informational traces they might have left
label: paragraph

line: were evidence of time travel from the past and not just simple knowledge of the past. Next, to the best of
label: paragraph

line: our knowledge, human technology to create a time machine does not exist in the past, so that time
label: paragraph

line: travelers from the past must originate in the future, assuming such technology is ever developed.
label: paragraph

line: 3 . Searching for Prescient Content on the Internet
label: paragraph

line: W ere a time traveler from the future to access the Internet of the past few years, they might have left
label: paragraph

line: once-prescient content that persists today. Alternatively, such information might have been placed on
label: paragraph

line: Internet by a third party discussing something unusual they have heard. Such content might have been
label: paragraph

line: catalogued by search engines such as Google (google.com) or Bing (bing.com), or remain in posts left on
label: paragraph

line: Facebook (facebook.com), Google Plus (plus.google.com), or Twitter (twitter.com).
label: paragraph

line: To make our search for such content manageable, a small number of search terms were sought that
label: paragraph

line: could conceivably give a relatively clear signal of prescient information in an automated query of a large
label: paragraph

line: database. The time period of our search was from 2006 January to 2013 September. Search terms were
label: paragraph

line: chosen to optimize three major attributes. First, search terms were sought that described an item or event
label: paragraph

line: that acquired a name during the time period of our search. Such terms would allow two different epochs
label: paragraph

line: to be compared -- potentially prescient content before this information became available, and normal
label: paragraph

line: content afterwards. For example, mentions of the "War of the Roses" occurred numerous times, but none
label: paragraph

line: that could easily be tagged in an automated search as even potentially prescient, since the actual Wars of
label: paragraph

line: the Roses ended in 1485, and the name "Wars of the Roses" only came into common usage in the 1800s,
label: paragraph

line: well before our automated searches began [19]. Therefore all discussions in our search period could be
label: paragraph

line: attributed to normal discussions of historic events.
label: paragraph

line: Second, search terms should involve as unique a label as possible. Were a large automated search
label: paragraph

line: focused on a common term, it would be difficult to automatically differentiate a prescient mention of this
label: paragraph

line: term from likely much more numerous common mentions. For example "Comet McNaught" was not
label: paragraph

line: considered to be a good search term because its discoverer, Robert H. McNaught, has discovered over 50
label: paragraph

line: comets dating as far back as 1987. Therefore, an automated search returning mentions of "Comet
label: paragraph

line: McNaught" in 2006, for example, could arguably not be returning prescient mentions of the impressively
label: paragraph

line: bright Comet McNaught in 2009, but rather mentions of one of the earlier-discovered comets that bears
label: paragraph

line: the same popular name.
label: paragraph

line: Third and last, search terms should remain well known and historically important into the future.
label: paragraph

line: Perennially famous objects or events might be more likely to be on the agendas of future time travelers,
label: paragraph

line: and so may permeate their Internet interactions. Not being time travelers ourselves, we cannot know for
label: paragraph

line: sure what present-day labels will remain popular into the future, but focusing on modern renditions of
label: paragraph

line: terms used by historically long-standing and internationally known institutions seemed pragmatic. Based
label: paragraph

line: on these criteria, two main labels were chosen: Comet ISON and Pope Francis.
label: paragraph

line: Comet ISON (C/2012 S1) is a comet that was discovered by the International Scientific Optical
label: paragraph

line: Network (ISON) on 2012 September 21. Therefore, the term "Comet ISON" came into the public lexicon
label: paragraph

line: during our search window. Although the ISON network had discovered one previous comet, that comet
label: paragraph

line: did not go by the popular name of Comet ISON. Therefore, the term "Comet ISON" is a unique label that
label: paragraph

line: should not be easily confused with something else. Comet ISON is internationally known and has been a
label: paragraph

line: topic of popular discussion on the Internet since its discovery. Histories of bright comets like Comet
label: paragraph

line: ISON are generally well kept by societies and journals around the world, indicating that Comet ISON
label: paragraph

line: might remain memorable well into the future. Conversely, there is little reason for anyone without
label: paragraph

line: prescient information to be referring to something as "Comet ISON" before 2012 September. Therefore,
label: paragraph

line: discussions or even mentions of "Comet ISON" before 2012 September were searched for as potentially
label: paragraph

line: prescient evidence of time travelers from the future.
label: paragraph

line: On 2013 March 16, the newly elected pope of the Catholic Church, Jorge Mario Bergoglio, chose the
label: paragraph

line: official name of Francis. Bergoglio is the first pope ever to choose the name Francis. Therefore, the term
label: paragraph

line: "Pope Francis" is relatively unique and came into the public lexicon during our search period. Since
label: paragraph

line: Christianity is currently the most popular religion on Earth, Roman Catholics comprise the largest sect of
label: paragraph

line: Christianity [20], and papal histories are well recorded, it seems reasonable to assume that "Pope Francis"
label: paragraph

line: would remain memorable well into the future. Before 2013 March, however, there is little reason for
label: paragraph

line: anyone without prescient information to mention a "Pope Francis". Discussions or even mentions on the
label: paragraph

line: Internet of Pope Francis before 2013 March were therefore searched for as potentially prescient evidence
label: paragraph

line: of time travelers from the future.
label: paragraph

line: A relatively efficient method for locating specific content on the voluminous Internet is through
label: paragraph

line: hashtags. Hashtagging -- labeling Internet content with terms beginning with a "#" -- originated on the
label: paragraph

line: Internet in the Internet Relay Chat (IRC) channels, which itself began in 1988 [21]. Hashtagging became
label: paragraph

line: prevalent on Twitter in 2007 as a means of signaling that information about given topics is available [22].
label: paragraph

line: In the past few years, hashtagging has become increasingly prevalent beyond Twitter and across the
label: paragraph

line: Internet, being used frequently on Facebook, Google Plus, blogs, and general Internet content. In essence,
label: paragraph

line: hashtags make information easier to find in online searches. We therefore typically included the
label: paragraph

line: hashtagged terms "#cometison" and "#popefrancis" in our searches. For example, when someone places
label: paragraph

line: content involving Comet ISON on the Internet, they might include the hashtag "#cometison". Since that
label: paragraph

line: hashtagged term would not occur in colloquial text, it acts as a label that can be found in a search by
label: paragraph

line: people seeking information about Comet ISON. Conversely, labeling and searching for the hashtagged
label: paragraph

line: term "#comet" or "#ISON" might not return information about only Comet ISON, but typically
label: paragraph

line: voluminous content involving other comets or other instances of the term "ison", a word that means
label: paragraph

line: "great" in Finnish.
label: paragraph

line: A direct way to search for information posted on the web is to use a commonly popular search engine.
label: paragraph

line: At the time of this writing, the most popular search engine is Google. Unfortunately, searching for
label: paragraph

line: prescient web content using the publicly available Google search has proven unreliable. Although
label: paragraph

line: providing the ability to sort identified content by date, several exploratory tests on Google found an
label: paragraph

line: initially surprising number of web pages that contained seemingly prescient information. Upon further
label: paragraph

line: inspection, however, all potentially-prescient content on those web pages was clearly non-prescient. One
label: paragraph

line: prominent reason for this was the appearance of recent advertisements on older news stories. Bing
label: paragraph

line: (bing.com), another currently popular search engine, did not appear to have a sufficient ability to filter
label: paragraph

line: results by posting date to be useful.
label: paragraph

line: Another place potentially prescient content might be found is on posts to the social network Facebook.
label: paragraph

line: At the time of this writing, Facebook is the most popular social network [23]. Facebook pages incorporate
label: paragraph

line: their own search engine. Unfortunately, searches on Facebook turned up results that were clearly not
label: paragraph

line: comprehensive. Searches for prescient posts on Facebook frequently culminated in an unexpectedly short
label: paragraph

line: listing, with text at the bottom stating "There are no more recent posts to show right now." The word
label: paragraph

line: "recent" was taken to indicate that the Facebook search did not report older, potentially prescient posts.
label: paragraph

line: Additionally, Facebook also allows backdated posts, as far back as the day the Facebook account was
label: paragraph

line: created. Such backdating undermines the ability of a search to determine whether information posted to
label: paragraph

line: Facebook is prescient. For example, someone who opened a Facebook account in 2006 could have posted
label: paragraph

line: a comment about "Pope Francis" in 2013 April and then backdated that post to 2008 April. In a search,
label: paragraph

line: we might discover this post and wrongly consider it prescient knowledge in 2008 that a "Pope Francis"
label: paragraph

line: would exist in the then-future 2013. However, even given Facebook's limited utility, searches found no
label: paragraph

line: prescient mentions of "Comet ISON", "Pope Francis", "#cometison", or "#popefrancis".
label: paragraph

line: Similarly, a preliminary search for prescient content on the social network Google Plus
label: paragraph

line: (plus.google.com) was terminated after it became clear that Google Plus did not always order search
label: paragraph

line: results temporally. It was
label: paragraph

line: informational mentions.
label: paragraph

line: therefore too difficult, in practice, to find older and potentially prescient
label: paragraph

line: Our most comprehensive search for potentially prescient Internet content was achieved using the
label: paragraph

line: microblogging Internet platform Twitter [24]. Twitter enables members to "tweet" posts up to 140
label: paragraph

line: characters. Twitter was created in 2006 and has been growing in popularity ever since. As of 2013 May,
label: paragraph

line: over 500 million active registered Twitter accounts produce over 1 billion tweets per month [24]. Even so,
label: paragraph

line: given the limited number of characters per tweet, a search using Twitter's own search engine appeared
label: paragraph

line: quick, comprehensive, had the ability to find tweets back to the very beginning of Twitter, and order the
label: paragraph

line: tweets temporally. Exploratory searches on Twitter indicated the ability to find all tweets that mentioned
label: paragraph

line: any of our preferred search terms. Also, Twitter does not allow backdated tweets. We therefore
label: paragraph

line: considered our search on Twitter to be our most comprehensive search for once-prescient content placed
label: paragraph

line: on the Internet.
label: paragraph

line: No clearly prescient content involving "Comet ISON", "#cometison", "Pope Francis", or
label: paragraph

line: "#popefrancis" was found from any Twitter tweet -- ever. One candidate was found -- an interesting
label: paragraph

line: speculative discussion using the term "Pope Francis" in a blog post advertised by a tweet, but upon close
label: paragraph

line: inspection and consideration, that blog post was deemed overtly speculative and not prescient. Searches
label: paragraph

line: were made both on the embedded Twitter search box and on the Twitter search service Topsy
label: paragraph

line: (topsy.com). Each of these search terms occurred numerous times -- hundreds for Comet ISON and
label: paragraph

line: thousands for Pope Francis -- but, with the one noted exception, only after 2012 September for Comet
label: paragraph

line: ISON and only after 2013 March for Pope Francis.
label: paragraph

line: Note that information once posted to the Internet may be subject to subsequent deletion by the poster,
label: paragraph

line: including content on the web, Facebook, and Twitter. Therefore, in general, information that was
label: paragraph

line: searched for potentially prescient content is that which remained on the Internet in August 2013.
label: paragraph

line: 4 . Searching for Prescient Search Queries
label: paragraph

line: A nother type of informational trace a time traveler from the future might have left on the modern-day
label: paragraph

line: Internet is a query to a current search engine for not-yet-available information. For example, a time
label: paragraph

line: traveler might have been trying to collect historical information that did not survive into the future, or
label: paragraph

line: might have searched for a prescient term because they erroneously thought that a given event had already
label: paragraph

line: occurred, or searched to see whether a given event was yet to occur. In an effort to uncover such prescient
label: paragraph

line: queries, we searched online databases for potentially prescient search terms themselves.
label: paragraph

line: Fortunately, searches using Google, the most popular search engine of the present time, are
label: paragraph

line: themselves searchable with Google Trends (google.com/trends) [25]. Google Trends was therefore used
label: paragraph

line: for a search for potentially prescient queries involving Comet Ison and Pope Francis. Although numerous
label: paragraph

line: searches were uncovered, none occurred sufficiently early to be considered prescient. Unfortunately
label: paragraph

line: however, we do not consider these negative results reliable. One reason is that the publicly available
label: paragraph

line: Google Trends only reported search results that had a significant "search volume" [25]. Therefore, for
label: paragraph

line: example, Google Trends did not report any instances of the term "#cometison" being searched for -- ever.
label: paragraph

line: And since we searched for this term ourselves, we know that at least some instances did occur. Next,
label: paragraph

line: Google Trends only reported on the prevalence of searches as normalized to the largest search volume in
label: paragraph

line: the desired time window, and not in absolute terms. Therefore, for example, search reports on "Comet
label: paragraph

line: ISON" reported a zero score for all days from January 2004 through September 2012, the month that
label: paragraph

line: Comet ISON was discovered, but numerous search queries thereafter. This zero score, however, was
label: paragraph

line: normalized to the peak score set to 100 for 2013 March. The raw numbers of searches for March 2013
label: paragraph

line: were not revealed by Google Trends. Therefore, to our understanding, the zero score really meant "less
label: paragraph

line: than 0.5 percent of the March 2013 value", which could well be greater than zero. Quite possibly, a single
label: paragraph

line: prescient search for Comet ISON would not have been recorded. Similarly Google Trends searches for
label: paragraph

line: the term "Pope Francis" gave a zero score for all times before 2013 March, and numerous searches
label: paragraph

line: thereafter, but was also not considered reliable. Neither Bing nor Yahoo! currently provide a public
label: paragraph

line: feature that allows a search over past queries.
label: paragraph

line: A search that was sensitive to a single potentially prescient query was in the log files for the primary
label: paragraph

line: internal search engine affiliated with the Astronomy Picture of the Day (APOD) web site (apod.nasa.gov),
label: paragraph

line: as housed at the USA's National Air and Space Administration (NASA) [26]. One of the authors (RJN) is
label: paragraph

line: an APOD site editor and is able to access daily log files which include queries sent to APOD's internal
label: paragraph

line: search engine. The inspected files did not contain personal information, and no attempts were made to
label: paragraph

line: connect any search information to any specific people.
label: paragraph

line: The NASA APOD web page is served with Apache software running under the Linux operating
label: paragraph

line: system. The search page used the URL apod.nasa.gov/cgi-bin/apod/apod_search. This page returned a
label: paragraph

line: search form that utilized the open source and free search software titled Simple Web Indexing System for
label: paragraph

line: Humans - Enhanced (Swish-e) [27]. For many years, including the time between 2006 January and 2009
label: paragraph

line: March, the NASA APOD search page HTML code used the "isindex" element to record and send back
label: paragraph

line: search terms to the web server at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center. This HTML code returned the
label: paragraph

line: search page URL appended with a suffix of a question mark followed by the search term to an indexed
label: paragraph

line: database previously catalogued by Swish-e. The returned query line was then indexed in a log file. For
label: paragraph

line: example, a search for "M31", without quotes, would result in the log file writing a line with the text
label: paragraph

line: "?M31" in it, without quotes.
label: paragraph

line: The NASA APOD log files were queried for potentially prescient search terms from the beginning of
label: paragraph

line: 2006 January through the end of 2009 March. Specifically, given that the Linux environment where the
label: paragraph

line: search was done was case sensitive, a search for either "?ISON", "?Ison", or "?ison" was conducted in the
label: paragraph

line: daily log files, quotes excluded. To make sure our search procedure was working, a concurrent search for
label: paragraph

line: the non-prescient term "?M31" was also conducted. M31 is the Messier catalog number for the
label: paragraph

line: Andromeda galaxy, a commonly used designation for a well-known astronomical object. The search for
label: paragraph

line: the "?M31" term uncovered many instances, typically several for each day searched, whereas only a
label: paragraph

line: handful of instances of any of the terms "?ISON", "?Ison", or "?ison" were ever found in the log files
label: paragraph

line: during this time period. Upon further investigation, each of these instances was related to extraneous
label: paragraph

line: information or misspellings, leaving no queries as possibly prescient.
label: paragraph

line: Starting in 2009 April, the way the NASA APOD search engine worked was changed so that queries
label: paragraph

line: submitted through the main APOD search page no longer typically recorded search results with a "?"
label: paragraph

line: prefix. Therefore, at that time, our search for prescient terms after this date could be incomplete, and
label: paragraph

line: potentially prescient searches missed.
label: paragraph

line: 5 . Requests for Time Travelers to Issue a Prescient Internet Communication
label: paragraph

line: I n addition to searching for prescient information that time travelers might have left archived passively on
label: paragraph

line: the Internet, another approach used was to make a request for time travelers to actively respond to a
label: paragraph

line: request for a prescient communication. The main idea was not to converse with individual time travelers,
label: paragraph

line: but rather to encourage a single interchange indicating that time travel has become possible in the future.
label: paragraph

line: The versatility of this approach allowed for the inclusion of additional information about whether time
label: paragraph

line: travel can alter these authors' past.
label: paragraph

line: An experiment designed to encourage such active communication was structured as follows. A post
label: paragraph

line: was created in 2013 September on a publicly available online bulletin board requesting that one of two
label: paragraph

line: hashtags be tweeted or emailed before a certain date.
label: paragraph

line: respond with a communication including either the
label: paragraph

line: "#ICannotChangeThePast2" on or before 2013 August.
label: paragraph

line: Specifically, time travelers were requested to
label: paragraph

line: hashtagged term "#ICanChangeThePast2" or
label: paragraph

line: A message incorporating the hashtagged term "#ICannotChangeThePast2" would indicate that time
label: paragraph

line: travel to the past is possible but that the time traveler believes that they do not have the ability to alter the
label: paragraph

line: authors' past. A universe where the past cannot be changed is termed as having a "fixed history", where
label: paragraph

line: history can be regarded as a single timeline. Such universes may uphold the Novikov Self-Consistency
label: paragraph

line: Conjecture [28]. For example, in a fixed history universe, nothing the time traveler could do would
label: paragraph

line: change the existence of the Wars of the Roses, so content involving that event could always be found by
label: paragraph

line: the authors on the Internet.
label: paragraph

line: Conversely, a message incorporating the hashtagged term "#ICanChangeThePast2" would indicate that
label: paragraph

line: time travel to the past is possible and that the time traveler can demonstrate the ability to alter the authors'
label: paragraph

line: past. Theoretical universes where the past can be changed are termed as having a "plastic history", where
label: paragraph

line: history cannot be regarded as a single timeline [29]. For example, in a plastic history universe, a time
label: paragraph

line: traveler might have the ability to go back and change history so that the Wars of the Roses never occurred
label: paragraph

line: in the past of the authors, with the result that the authors would not be able to find content about this
label: paragraph

line: event on the Internet. Time travel in a plastic history universe could introduce seeming logical
label: paragraph

line: conundrums such as the "grandfather paradox" [30], where the time traveler's grandfather, for example,
label: paragraph

line: could be killed young enough to sabotage the very existence of the time traveler. It is not the purpose of
label: paragraph

line: this section to detail, debate, or resolve logical conundrums convolved with plastic histories -- just to
label: paragraph

line: carry out a simple test for them.
label: paragraph

line: In 2013 August we searched all of Twitter for the hashtag "#ICanChangeThePast2" and found no
label: paragraph

line: occurrences. Starting in 2013 September, time travelers were publically requested to go into their past and
label: paragraph

line: tweet "#ICanChangeThePast2" before 2013 August to demonstrate this ability. After this request, later in
label: paragraph

line: 2013 September, we again searched Twitter for the same hashtag, but only for a tweet with a posting date
label: paragraph

line: before 2013 August, as requested. For such a tweet to have been found only in the second search and not
label: paragraph

line: the first, a time traveler would have had to have known about the advertisement posted in 2013
label: paragraph

line: September, go back in time to before 2013 August, send the prescient tweet, and have this tweet appear
label: paragraph

line: only in our later Twitter search in 2013 September. Assuming no spoofing, the only way this can happen
label: paragraph

line: is if time travelers can change our past with their actions.
label: paragraph

line: Similarly, in 2013 August, we searched the cataloged email sent to "home.nemiroff@yahoo.com" for a
label: paragraph

line: communication with the term "#ICanChangeThePast2" in the subject line and found no occurrences.
label: paragraph

line: Starting in 2013 September, time travelers were publically requested to go into their past and send an
label: paragraph

line: email with "#ICanChangeThePast2" in the subject line to "home.nemiroff@yahoo.com" before anytime
label: paragraph

line: between 2008 November, the month after this email address was created, and 2013 August.
label: paragraph

line: Alternatively, time travelers who believe that they cannot change the past were requested to tweet
label: paragraph

line: "#ICannotChangeThePast2" on or before 2013 August, or include that hashtag at the end of an email sent
label: paragraph

line: to "home.nemiroff@yahoo.com" between 2008 November and 2013 August.
label: paragraph

line: experiment, we were careful NOT to search Twitter or email until after the
label: paragraph

line: For this part of the
label: paragraph

line: hashtag was publicly
label: paragraph

line: advertised in 2013 September. Therefore, by not pursuing a pre-advertisement search, the past might not
label: paragraph

line: have had to be changed in order for this tweet to have been discovered in 2013 September.
label: paragraph

line: Advantages of using Twitter for this active search include that tweets are discoverable by anyone with
label: paragraph

line: sufficient access to the Internet and so are publically falsifiable. Advantages to using email include the
label: paragraph

line: relative ease of acquiring even a temporary email account, and the relative amount of privacy -- perhaps
label: paragraph

line: preferred by the time traveler -- inherent in a private email message.
label: paragraph

line: Unfortunately, as of this writing, no prescient tweets or emails were received. Given the additional
label: paragraph

line: exposure that the public listing of this manuscript gains, we will continue to search, on occasion, for
label: paragraph

line: active tweets and emails involving potential time travel.
label: paragraph

line: 6 . Summary and Conclusions
label: paragraph

line: T he discovery of time travel into the past could be transformative not only to physics but humanity. Its
label: paragraph

line: uses might be many and varied -- probably enlightening, but possibly catastrophic. Unlike modern
label: paragraph

line: searches for dark matter and dark energy, however, modern searches for time travel are comparatively
label: paragraph

line: rare. Given the modern ubiquity of the Internet, though, there now exists new, far reaching, and falsifiable
label: paragraph

line: methods to search for time travelers.
label: paragraph

line: Technically, what was searched for here was not physical time travelers themselves, but rather
label: paragraph

line: informational traces left by them. Although such information might be left by physical time travelers,
label: paragraph

line: conceivably only information itself could be sent back in time, which would be a type of time travel that
label: paragraph

line: might not directly involve the backwards transport of a significant amount of energy or momentum. This
label: paragraph

line: might be considered, by some, a more palatable mode of backwards time travel than transferring
label: paragraph

line: significant amounts of matter or energy back in time, as the later might break, quite coarsely, local
label: paragraph

line: conservation of energy and momentum [31]. For example, were the same person at different epochs to
label: paragraph

line: stand next to themselves, the energy tied into their own rest mass seems not to have been conserved.
label: paragraph

line: Similarly, instantaneous time travel to the same place on Earth might violate conservation of momentum,
label: paragraph

line: as the motion of the Earth around the Sun (etc.) might delegate a significant change in momentum for a
label: paragraph

line: corporeal object even over a time scale of minutes.
label: paragraph

line: Although the negative results reported here may indicate that time travelers from the future are not
label: paragraph

line: among us and cannot communicate with us over the modern day Internet, they are by no means proof.
label: paragraph

line: There are many reasons for this. First, it may be physically impossible for time travelers to leave any
label: paragraph

line: lasting remnants of their stay in the past, including even non-corporeal informational remnants on the
label: paragraph

line: Internet. Next, it may be physically impossible for us to find such information as that would violate some
label: paragraph

line: yet-unknown law of physics, possibly similar to the Chronology Protection Conjecture [16]. Furthermore,
label: paragraph

line: time travelers may not want to be found, and may be good at covering their tracks. Additionally, time
label: paragraph

line: travelers just may not have left the specific event tags that we were searching for. Finally, our searches
label: paragraph

line: were not comprehensive, so that even if time travelers left the exact event tags searched for here, we
label: paragraph

line: might have missed them due to human error, oversight, incompleteness of Internet catalogs and searches,
label: paragraph

line: or inaccurate content time tags.
label: paragraph

line: Nevertheless, given the current prevalence of the Internet, its numerous portals around the globe, and
label: paragraph

line: its numerous uses in communication, this search might
label: paragraph

line: comprehensive search yet for time travel from the future.
label: paragraph
